tossups.question: This instrument forms part of the stage name of a musician whose "swamp"-style hits included "Baby Scratch My Back" and "I'm a King Bee." Virtuosos on this instrument include Junior Wells, as well as a musician who described a spouse who "can't stand no cheatin'" on the hit "My Babe." The Hohner (HO-ner) company is best-known for producing this main instrument of Little Walter, one type of which can increase its pitch by a semitone with a button-operated sliding bar. Richter tuning gives the 19 basic notes available on one type of this instrument, which can be extended by blues players to produce a "wail" using a form of vibrato called "bending." This instrument's single-key diatonic type has 20 reeds and 10 holes. Neck racks are often used to hold, for 10 points, what small instruments, whose players blow between two metal reed plates?

tossups.question: One side of this equation reduces to "r squared minus one, all over r squared plus one" in a case named after photons. An additive quantity given by this equation is plotted against the date on porkchop plots. One derivation of this equation converts a Riemann (REE-man) sum over N "pellets" to a definite integral of a term proportional to "1 over 1 minus phi." A term in this equation is written as the product of a quantity measured in seconds denoted "I-sub-s-p" with specific gravity. This equation, which is usually derived using an infinitesimal application of the impulse-momentum principle, relates a change in velocity to the log of the ratio of two masses, one including the propellant and one without. tossups.question: This city's "General Intendant" Paulo Vianna was responsible for replacing much of its early Arab-influenced architecture. Joachim Lebreton (joh-ah-KEEM lay-BRAY-ton) led a mission of French artists in this city that served as the basis for a later national academy. Anecdotally, the letters P.R. were said to stand for "get out" on royal eviction notices posted in this city to support thousands of nobles who immigrated in the 1810s. Euclides da Cunha (yoo-KLEE-deez dai COIN-yuh) popularized the name for a hilltop slum in this city populated by disgruntled veterans from the War of Canudos. Prior to 1831, millions of slaves were sold through this city's Valongo Wharf, which handled around 40 percent of the transatlantic slave trade. This city became a "tropical Versailles" after John IV of Portugal moved his royal court here during the Peninsular War. For 10 points, name this port in Brazil.

tossups.question: In 2005, historian Paul Cartledge was made an honorary citizen of this city for books such as a 1989 text examining it in "Hellenistic and Roman" eras. Sarah Pomeroy wrote the first book-length history of women in this city, including an attempt to build a "female robot as evil and deceptive as Pandora" dressed in the jewels of the evil wife Apega by this city's tyrant Nabis. Over 100,000 lead (led) votives were found starting in 1906 in the excavation of this city, which also found the sanctuary of Artemis Orthia, the site of a cheese-flogging ritual. Plutarch wrote that women from this city used wine to bathe newborns in order to euthanize epileptic children. This city's government included five elders called ephoroi (EE-for-oi). tossups.question: The Church of the East uses a "Holy" variety of this stuff called Malka. Although it is used in palappam, Saint Thomas Christians do not use this stuff in creating pesaha appam. Because the latter put this stuff in their prosphora, Members of the Latin Church called Eastern Christians "prozymites" in response to Easterners calling Westerners "azymites" during disputes leading to the Great Schism. Among some Hasidim, anything that naturally contains this stuff and sits for more than 18 minutes after absorbing liquid is considered chametz. While Catholics believe this stuff symbolizes sin, Eastern Christians memorialize the Resurrection by consuming Host made with this ingredient in the Eucharist. This character claims that "there is only one cock in the basket" after another character worries that "the triangle" may be broken up. After confessing that she has "lost [her] faith in the vine-leaves," this character gives one of her friends a "memento" of a pistol and asks him to use it "beautifully." He's not Habakkuk, but a sculptor allegedly slapped the knee of a sculpture of this man and shouted, "Now speak!" tossups.question: This phenomenon partially names an index whose value is the average of the RON ("R O N") and MON ("M O N") and is often written as "R plus M, all over 2." To decrease this phenomenon's frequency, one can reduce the manifold pressure or reduce the ratio abbreviated AFR. An Achille Mbembe (um-BEM-bay) essay discusses performing this process in "the university." Eve Tuck and K. An essay collection titled for this process asserts that English has been a "cultural bomb" and advocates the use of Kikuyu. tossups.question: According to Jewish legend, the Milcham shrinks to the size of one of these objects every 1000 years as part of its reward for not eating from the Tree of Life. Impundulu leave these objects underground near lightning strikes in Zulu myth. Garuda's mother was enslaved after breaking one of these objects, causing Aruna to have the strength of the morning sun. The goddess Hi'iaka is named for these objects in reference to Pele earlier carrying one of them to Hawai'i in her armpit. On Sinbad's fifth voyage, Rocs attack the crew after they eat a giant one of these objects. Commonly held to symbolize Taiji, one of these objects containing Pangu split to form the heavens and the earth in Chinese mythology. For 10 points, a common mythological motif involves the world hatching from what objects?
tossups.formatted_answer: eggs

tossups.question: These drugs were shown by Franks and Lieb to inhibit luciferase at pharmacologic concentrations. These drugs namesake cutoff effect occurs when lengthening their carbon chains past a certain point. Per the Meyer-Overton hypothesis, the potency of these drugs is inversely proportional to their lipid solubility. Their potency is inversely proportional to their minimum alveolar concentration. Sevoflurane (sev-OH-flor-ain) and desflurane (DEZ-flor-ain) are medications in this class. One side effect of these medications is treated with dantrolene (DAN-troh-leen) and occurs in patients with a mutation in the ryanodine receptor, that side effect is as malignant hyperthermia. William T. G. Morton demonstrated the use of these medications at Mass General in a room now known as the Ether Dome. For 10 points, name these medications that render patients unconscious before surgery.
tossups.formatted_answer: inhalational anesthetics

tossups.question: A Larghetto movement by this composer has the orchestra echoing the soloist's opening theme, which begins "B-flat, dotted eighth sixteenth B-flats, slurred eighth B-flat E-flat; E-flat." This composer quoted the overture from La calamita de'couri by J. C. Bach in a "little" companion to a concerto whose second movement's opening 6/8 Adagio Siciliana in F-sharp minor was this composer's only use of that key. Cuthbert Girdlestone wrote an oft-read study on this mentor of Barbara Ployer, whose piano sonatas and concerti were all recorded by Mitsuko Uchida. He wrote one concerto for Victoire Jenamy, and another nicknamed for its performance at Leopold II's crowning. Jeunehomme (ZHUN-ohm), Coronation, and Elvira Madigan are among this composer's 27 piano concerti. For 10 points, what composer's A major eleventh piano sonata ends with his Rondo alla turca?

tossups.question: Albert Szent-Györgyi (sen-yorg-yee) discovered a "hexuronic" (hex-yoor-ON-ik) substance that prevented this condition. A liquid that was purported to treat this condition called "rob" was actually rendered ineffective during the boiling process. Believing this disease to be caused by putrefaction, James Lind experimented with cider, vinegar, and diluted sulfuric acid to treat this condition. Lauchlin Rose's patent for preservation without alcohol led him to supply goods combating this condition, whose prevalence created an old American slang for British people. Sauerkraut consumption helped prevent Captain Cook's men from succumbing to this disease, which can be combated by almost any fruit or vegetable product but was ultimately addressed in the Royal Navy with fresh citrus. Sailors formerly suffered from, for 10 points, what disease caused by a lack of vitamin C?
tossups.formatted_answer: scurvy [prompt on vitamin C deficiency] [Rob was a lemon juice concentrate that had its vitamin C destroyed when boiled.]

tossups.question: An appendix to this collection criticizes the "hubbub of words" used to paraphrase a Biblical proverb in the poem "The Ant." The "Advertisement" included in the first edition of this collection describes its "experiment" with the language of "the middle and lower classes." This collection, whose preface describes "the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings," includes a poem that ends, "once more, my friends! farewell," subtitled a "conversation poem." In a poem in this collection, the narrator recalls seeing "steep woods and lofty cliffs" with his sister Dorothy. That poem in this collection notes that "five years have past; five summers, with the length of five long winters" since its author last visited the area near Tintern Abbey. tossups.question: This mathematician opposed the claim that axioms are definitions during a controversy with David Hilbert. This founder of the logicist program's namesake metatheorem states that Hume's principle can be used to derive all the Peano axioms in second-order logic. This thinker names a type of puzzle that concerns such statements as "a = b" and "a = a" where a and b have differing "cognitive values." This mathematician's axiom scheme of unrestricted comprehension, or Basic Law Five, was shown to be inconsistent when applied to the set of sets that don't contain themselves by Bertrand Russell. This thinker stated that, although "Hesperus" and "Phosphorus" indicate the same planet, the names express different things. For 10 points, name this mathematical philosopher who penned Foundations of Arithmetic and the paper "On Sense and Reference."

bonuses.leadin: Rita Lavelle was convicted for perjury related to mismanagement of funds for this agency in the 1980s. For 10 points each:
parts: Paulette Barnes successfully sued what government agency, after she was fired for refusing her supervisor's advances, in what is now seen as the first sexual harassment case in the United States?
The EPA was established under this president, who visited Mao Zedong in China in 1972.

In 2022, the EPA announced a civil rights investigation into some of this state's agencies over allegations that Black residents are disproportionately affected by pollution along its so-called "Cancer Alley," which is home to a cluster of 30 factories including Denka's neoprene plant, Shintech's ethylene plant, and TotalEnergy's facility that is the world's largest producer of styrofoam.

bonuses.leadin: The truth and oneness of God are referenced by the names Satnam and Ik Onkar in this religion's Mul Mantar. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this religion that venerates God as the "wondrous teacher" Waheguru. That name appears in its Adi Granth.
The Sikh name Akal Purakh describes this attribute of God. As the first Jathedar, Bhai Gurdas sat on the Golden Temple's Akal Takht, a throne named for having this attribute.
Bhai Gurdas attests that God's name Waheguru originates from combining the mantras of these four cyclic epochs of existence in Hindu cosmology. A thousand of them make up a kalpa.
answers: eternal [or obvious equivalents such as timeless or immortal or non-temporal]
formatted_answers: eternal [or obvious equivalents such as timeless or immortal or non-temporal]

bonuses.leadin: This artist, whose 1911 pictures of Paul Poiret's gowns for Art et Decoration magazine were the first modern fashion photographs, was chief photographer for Vogue and Vanity Fair in much of the 20s and 30s. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this curator of the MoMA's The Family of Man exhibit, whose commercial turn was bemoaned by fellow Photo-Secessionist Alfred Stieglitz.

Steichen's photograph of Gloria Swanson behind a veil does not show this trademark facial feature of hers. A celebrated Vogue cover only shows Jean Patchett's eye, lips, and one of these moles whose two-word name reflects their attractive status.
Swanson was a client of this Polish-Jewish popularizer of the noun "make-up," who used a "beauty micrometer" to analyze faces. His namesake company moved a drawn "X" from inside its logo to the end.

bonuses.leadin: Motors described by this prefix include the "electron windmill" constructed using two gold-plated electrodes. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this prefix used to refer to both the distance of "10 to the minus 9 meters," and to the unusual technology that could exist at that scale.

In this 1959 lecture on nanotechnology, Richard Feynman offered a $1000 prize to whoever first made a nanomotor, only for William McLellan to win the prize by very intricately using traditional tools.

A reversed quantum pump technique is used in theoretical quantum nanomotors described by this adjective. In processes described by this adjective, pressure times volume to the power gamma is conserved.
answers: "There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom" [or "There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom: An Invitation to Enter a New Field of Physics"]
formatted_answers: "There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom" [or "There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom: An Invitation to Enter a New Field of Physics"]

bonuses.leadin: T. S. Eliot discussed how every generation reinvents this author in a lecture on this author "and the Stoicism of Seneca." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this playwright. One of this author's plays is called an "artistic failure" in an Eliot essay that introduced the "objective correlative," titled "Hamlet and his Problems."

In "Tradition and the Individual Talent," Eliot notes that Shakespeare "acquired more essential history from Plutarch than most men could from" this place. Another poet-critic, William Empson, declared, "Let us offer our pinch of dust all to this God" in an "Homage to" this place.
Eliot's essays were a major influence on this American critical movement, whose members included Cleanth Brooks. This movement advocated close reading of poems in isolation.
answers: William Shakespeare [or "Shakespeare and the Stoicism of Seneca"]
formatted_answers: William Shakespeare [or "Shakespeare and the Stoicism of Seneca"]

bonuses.leadin: Along with Filippo Marinetti, a former proponent of this ideology named Alceste De Ambris (al-SES-tay day am-BREES) co-authored the "Fascist Manifesto." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ideology which advocates for control of the government by workers' unions. During the Two Red Years, the USI promoted a variant of this ideology that fuses its ideas with anarchism.
The "Fascist Manifesto" became the official political doctrine for this Italian prime minister during World War II.

The "Fascist Manifesto" originally called for the abolition of the Italian Senate; however, Mussolini later engineered this law, stating that the party that gained the plurality of votes would receive two-thirds of parliamentary seats. This law ensured that the 1924 elections were the last in Italy until the postwar period.

bonuses.leadin: A news channel for this ethnicity, Channel S, was paid by a mayor of this ethnicity for biased coverage prior to a 2014 election in Tower Hamlets. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ethnicity, which now makes up a majority of the East London neighborhood of Spitalfields after immigrating from Sylhet.

After becoming Britain's first mayor to be removed due to electoral fraud, Lutfur Rahman was replaced by John Biggs, a member of this party. This current main British opposition party is led by Sir Keir Starmer.

After serving a five-year ban from office, Rahman won the mayoralty again in a 2022 election against a Lib Dem candidate with this surname. Since beating Shaun Bailey in a 2021 election, another politician of this surname has been blamed for rising knife crime.

bonuses.leadin: This artist stated that painting "can only consist of the representation of objects which are visible and tangible" in an open letter called the "Realist Manifesto." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French realist painter who depicted a disinterested crowd at a funeral in A Burial at Ornans.

Critics shamed the central figures in this 1857 realist painting as the "Three Fates of Poverty" in reference to their red, blue, and white bonnets representing the tricolour. Women collect wheat after a harvest in this painting.
This other realist painting features twelve oxen in groups of six trudging across a field. This painting may have been inspired by the opening scene of George Sand's novel La Mare au Diable.
answers: Ploughing in the Nivernais [or Laborage Nivernais; or Oxen Plowing in Nevers; or Ploughing in Nivernais] [by Rosa Bonheur]
formatted_answers: Ploughing in the Nivernais [or Laborage Nivernais; or Oxen Plowing in Nevers; or Ploughing in Nivernais] [by Rosa Bonheur]

bonuses.leadin: Hyperconjugation may explain why this conformation is sometimes more stable than the anti conformation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this conformation characterized by two substituted groups having a dihedral angle between 0 and 120 degrees, which is generally more stable than eclipsed and synperiplanar conformations.

Gauche conformations can be visualized using these diagrams. These projections depict conformational isomers by representing molecules with a front atom as a dot and the back atoms as a circle surrounding it.
These molecules cannot have a gauche conformation because they are non-substituted. These acyclic hydrocarbons are characterized by only having single bonds.

bonuses.leadin: Eleanor Robson credits this author's popularity to Marta Weigle's 1978 article "Women as Verbal Artists." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this priestess of Nanna from Ur, whom Weigle touted as the "first known author in world literature."

Two poems of this type attributed to Enheduanna survive in multiple copies because of their use in the scribal education program called the Decad. Thirty-three poems of this type addressed to various deities are called "Homeric" because of their use of dactylic hexameter.

Oddly, Enheduanna used this language's standard Emegir variety instead of its feminine Emesal dialect. Cuneiform was created to write this language, which was gradually replaced in daily speech by Akkadian and used for a namesake king list.

bonuses.leadin: Secret police attacked American reporters covering a protest by members of this religion in the Double Seven Day Scuffle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this religion, whose namesake "crisis" resulted in the assassination of Ngô Đình Diệm (NOH ding ZEE-em) after raids on its buildings such as the Xá Lợi (SAH loy) Pagoda.

This man's death temporarily alleviated the Buddhist crisis by prompting the signing of the Joint Communiqué. Malcolm Browne photographed this Buddhist monk self-immolating in Saigon in June 1963 to protest persecution in South Vietnam.

Nine Buddhists were killed in this city after raising a Buddhist flag on Vesak. Members of the ARVN poured tear gas on praying Buddhists as part of a series of chemical attacks in this city, which was later the site of a monthlong battle during the Tet Offensive.
answers: Thích Quảng Đức [or Thích Quảng Đức; or Lâm Văn Túc; or Lâm Văn Túc]
formatted_answers: Thích Quảng Đức [or Thích Quảng Đức; or Lâm Văn Túc; or Lâm Văn Túc]

bonuses.leadin: These structures fall off in a process called abscission. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these structures that fall off deciduous trees each autumn.
When the abscission layer cuts off the vein going to a leaf, this phenomenon can result, in which the dead leaves of a deciduous tree remain attached to the tree throughout winter.

In marcescence, this structure remains alive through winter. The abscission zone forms at the base of this structure, which is the stalk that connects the leaf to the stem, and which is absent in sessile leaves.

bonuses.leadin: This work concludes with a Letter to the Reader written by Brother Silent in which the author explains that this work is presenting "an unhappy love affair." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work that contrasts a "dialectic of inward deepening" form and a "paradoxical" form of religiousness. Its first section, "In Vino Veritas," is modeled after Plato's Symposium.
Stages on Life's Way was written as a continuation of this work by the same author. This 1843 work, which contrasts the "aesthetic" and "ethical" stages, includes the "Diary of a Seducer."
Stages on Life's Way and Either/Or were both written by this Danish philosopher, respectively under the pseudonyms "Hilarius Bookbinder" and "Victor Eremita."
answers: Stages on Life's Way [or Stadier paa Livets Vej]
formatted_answers: Stages on Life's Way [or Stadier paa Livets Vej]

bonuses.leadin: James Alcock's book Back from the Future criticizes this psychologist's article "Feeling the Future", in which he claimed to have found evidence for ESP. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this psychologist, who used a variation on the Festinger-Carlsmith experiment to justify his self-perception theory.
Criticisms of "Feeling the Future" fueled a namesake "crisis" of this procedure that involves performing a prior experiment again to confirm the validity of its results.

This psychologist claimed that asking "unthinkable" questions could solve the replication crisis because of the "publish or perish" culture of research. This psychologist developed realistic conflict theory after examining the formation of ingroups in the Robbers Cave experiment.

bonuses.leadin: Vincent Starrett popularized a "Game" in which details of this character's life are inferred from the minutiae of the works they appear in. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who claims to be the great-nephew of the artist Horace Vernet (vair-NAY). William S. Baring-Gould claimed that this character's father is called Siger (SEE-ger), since this character uses Sigerson as a false name.
Holmesian scholars often try to resolve the inconsistencies in the backstory of this doctor, a frequent companion of Holmes.

A classic inconsistency is that Watson's war wound is in his shoulder in A Study in Scarlet, but is in his leg in this second Sherlock Holmes novel. Major Sholto and Mary Morstan are introduced in this novel, in which Holmes investigates the Agra treasure.
answers: The Sign of Four [or The Sign of the Four]
formatted_answers: The Sign of Four [or The Sign of the Four]

bonuses.leadin: This man's lieutenant, Lawrence Kemys (KEE-miss), stabbed himself to death after this man refused his apology for an attack on a Spanish outpost that resulted in the death of his son. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this explorer who wrote the 1596 book The Discovery of Guiana (gee-AH-nuh), but who never found El Dorado during his two voyages to South America.

Walter Raleigh twice attempted to establish a settlement on this island in present day North Carolina. The word "CROATOAN" was carved into a fencepost by inhabitants of a "lost colony" on this island.
This artist served as governor of the second colony on Roanoke Island. This grandfather of Virginia Dare went back to England in 1587 for more supplies and found Roanoke deserted upon his return.

bonuses.leadin: Jayne Birkby led a team that discovered water in this body's atmosphere in 2017 based on data from the Very Large Telescope. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this object discovered in 1995 by Michel Mayor (MI-shell MAY-or) and Didier Queloz (did-ee-ay KAY-lozz) using the ELODIE (EH-low-dee) spectrograph, for which they were awarded the 2019 Nobel Prize for Physics.
51 Pegasi b exemplifies a class of "hot" exoplanets named for their resemblance to this largest planet in the Solar System.

The water in 51 Pegasi b's atmosphere was discovered by observing shifts in this specific quantity. Like many exoplanets, 51 Pegasi b was itself discovered using a method named for this quantity, variations in which cause Doppler shifts.
answers: 51 Pegasi b [or 51 Peg b or Dimidium or Bellerophon; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
formatted_answers: 51 Pegasi b [or 51 Peg b or Dimidium or Bellerophon; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]

bonuses.leadin: Gavin Bryars' 2013 viol consort In Nomine is subtitled "For" this Baroque composer, whose brother Michael and son Edward were also composers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this English composer drawn from in Michael Nyman's "Chasing Sheep is Best Left to Shepherds" and Britten's Young Person's Guide. His operas include King Arthur and Dido and Aeneas.

The In Nomine genre developed from the Benedictus of a mass by a composer who essentially shares his name with the "holy minimalist" Orthodox composer of Song for Athene and The Protecting Veil. Name either.

Max Davies used Taverner's In Nomine theme in an opera and two pieces of this type named for him. Another piece of this type for double string orchestra and string quartet was premiered at the 1910 Three Choirs Festival.
answers: John Taverner OR the later John Kenneth Tavener (allegedly, distant relatives)
fantasia [or fantasy] [the latter is the Tallis Fantasia by Ralph ("rafe") Vaughan Williams]
formatted_answers: John Taverner OR the later John Kenneth Tavener (allegedly, distant relatives)
fantasia [or fantasy] [the latter is the Tallis Fantasia by Ralph ("rafe") Vaughan Williams]

bonuses.leadin: This novel is divided into ten sections corresponding to the ten sefirot enumerated in Kabbalah. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel in which Casaubon, Belbo, and Diotallevi use a computer called Abulafia to process Colonel Ardenti's manuscript, outputting a conspiracy about "telluric currents" focused on the title instrument in the Musée des Arts et Metiers.
A Boston Globe reviewer called Umberto Eco's Foucault's Pendulum a "thinking man's" version of this Dan Brown novel in which Robert Langdon uncovers a conspiracy involving the title painter.

"The Plan" in Foucault's Pendulum involves a number of groups, including the Gnostics, whose creation myth is recounted to the protagonist of this Eco novel on his quest to visit Prester John's kingdom.

bonuses.leadin: A king of Argos with this name wounds Ares and Aphrodite in a passage from Books V and VI of the Iliad that some scholars believe was originally its own poem. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this name shared by a king of the Bistonians whose flesh-eating mares are stolen in Heracles' eighth labor.

The aforementioned Homeric passage is the longest classical example of this epic convention in which a warrior's most excellent moments are highlighted. Thus, this type of scene takes its name from the Greek for "best."

In her aristeia, the Volsci queen Camilla slays twelve and dies while fighting alongside this King of the Rutuli. Aeneas almost spares this Achilles-like warrior, but his rage takes over when he sees him wearing Pallas's belt.

bonuses.leadin: In one origin story, the man who became this god fails to notice money his former wife hides in some cakes and kills himself, but is kept from becoming a "hopping vampire" by divine intervention. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this analogue of the Vietnamese god Mandarin Tao, whose paper effigy may be bribed with honey before it is burned on "Little New Year."
Ancestor veneration may involve burning paper described by this Portuguese-derived word of Chinese Pidgin English. It also describes incense sticks used in Chinese folk religion.
In another fiery ritual, Chinese men carry women with this condition over burning coals. Several toilet goddesses, like Zigu, protect women with this condition granted by fertility deities.
answers: the Kitchen God [or the Stove God; or the Hearth God; or Zao Jun; or Zao Shen; or Zao kimjah; or Cokimjah; or Zhang Lang]
joss [or joss paper; or joss sticks] (ultimately derives from Portuguese "deus," meaning "god")
formatted_answers: the Kitchen God [or the Stove God; or the Hearth God; or Zao Jun; or Zao Shen; or Zao kimjah; or Cokimjah; or Zhang Lang]
joss [or joss paper; or joss sticks] (ultimately derives from Portuguese "deus," meaning "god")
